comment.content:
This is used to determine the width of the search field in about:preferences,
in order to make the entire placeholder string visible

Please keep the placeholder string short to avoid truncation.

Notice: The value of the `.style` attribute is a CSS string, and the `width`
is the name of the CSS property. It is intended only to adjust the element's width.
Do not translate.

comment.content:
"Firefox" should be treated as a brand and kept in English,
while "Home" and "(Default)" can be localized.

This string has a special case for '1' and [other] (default). If necessary for
your language, you can add {$tabCount} to your translations and use the
standard CLDR forms, or only use the form for [other] if both strings should
be identical.

elements.value: Use the address bar for search and navigation
Choose the default search engine to use in the address bar and search bar.
Show search suggestions in address bar results
Show search suggestions ahead of browsing history in address bar results

comment.content:
This string describes what the user will observe when the system
prioritizes search suggestions over browsing history in the results
that extend down from the address bar. In the original English string,
"ahead" refers to location (appearing most proximate to), not time
(appearing before).

elements.value: Search suggestions will not be shown in location bar results because you have configured

comment.content: This message contains two links and two icon images. `` - Android logo icon `` - Link to Android Download `` - iOS logo icon `` - Link to iOS Download They can be moved within the sentence as needed to adapt to your language, but should not be changed or translated.

elements.value: Choose what to synchronize on your devices using
A list of what’s open on all synced devices
Names, numbers and expiry dates (desktop only)
Extensions and themes for Firefox desktop
General, Privacy, and Security settings you’ve changed
Ask to save logins and passwords for websites

comment.content:
This label is followed, on the same line, by a dropdown list of options
(Remember history, etc.).
In English it visually creates a full sentence, e.g.
"Firefox will" + "Remember history".

If this doesn't work for your language, you can translate this message:
  - Simply as "Firefox", moving the verb into each option.
    This will result in "Firefox" + "Will remember history", etc.
  - As a stand-alone message, for example "Firefox history settings:".

elements.value: will remember your browsing, download, form and search history.
will use the same settings as private browsing, and will not remember any history as you browse the Web.

  $unit (String) - Name of the unit (for example: "bytes", "KB")

comment.content:
This label means 'type of content that is blocked', and is followed by a drop-down list with content types below.
The list items are the strings named sitedata-block-*-option*.

Block third-party content that tracks you around the web. Control how much of your online activity gets stored and shared between websites.

comment.content:
The terminology used to refer to categories of Content Blocking is also used in chrome/browser/browser.properties and should be translated consistently.
"Standard" in this case is an adjective, meaning "default" or "normal".

elements.value: Only blocks known trackers in Private Windows.
Balanced for protection and performance. Allows some trackers so websites function properly.
detects. May cause some sites to break.
Known trackers only in Private Windows
Blocking content can cause some websites to break. It’s easy to disable blocking for sites you trust.

comment.content: Cryptomining refers to using scripts on websites that can use a computer’s resources to mine cryptocurrency without a user’s knowledge.

Browser fingerprinting is a method of tracking users by the configuration and settings information (their "digital fingerprint")
that is visible to websites they browse, rather than traditional tracking methods such as IP addresses and unique cookies.

elements.value: Block websites from automatically playing sound

for everyone. We always ask permission before receiving personal information.
